Description: Fragment of Attic red-figured pottery open vase, probably krater. Glazed inside; outside part of male figure seated on a rock, facing left; draped with chlamys and holding a club in his left hand.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Antikenmuseum, Heidelberg. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
W. Kraiker, Die rotfigurigen attischen Vasen (1978) 52,199, Suppl. pl. 11,199. Heidelberg, Antikenmuseum I52-I77 and I85-I92 have in the past been erroneously known and cited as J52-77 and J85-92.

The figure might be taken to be Herakles or Theseus, but the fact that he is facing left gives doubt. Theseus' first opponent on his return to Athens, Periphetes, might be considered, though in other preserved scenes he is not clothed.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1111)
